--- In archive-crawler@yahoogro=
ups.com, "Kristinn Sigurdsson"
<kris@...> wrote:
>
> Probably the easiest w=
ay to do this is to have the mid-fetch filter
> 'tag' the CrawlURI (using C=
rawlURI.put methods) and then have a
> processor run directly after the Fet=
chHTTP processor that checks for
> this tag. Filters are not allowed to aff=
ect the order of processing,
> but processors are. The new processor could =
then skip CrawlURIs with
> the tag to the PostProcessing chain, bypassing l=
ink extraction and
> writing processors.
> 
> The new processor's innerProc=
ess method would look something like:
> 
> if(curi.containsKey(MY_TAG) && c=
uri.getInt(MY_TAG)=3D=3DABORTED_MID_FETCH){
>   
>
curi.skipToProcessorChai=
n(getController().getProcessorChainList().getProcessorChain(CrawlOrder.ATTR=
_POST_PROCESSORS));
> 
> }
> 
> - Kris
> 
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogro=
ups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@> wrote:
> >
> > The mid-fetch filter is priva=
te to the FetchHTTP processor and has no 
> > effects outside that processo=
r.
> > 
> > If you want an URL to not even begin processing, it should be
r=
uled-out 
> > by the scope rules. If you want it to not be written, rules i=
nside
the 
> > writer processor can cause writing to be skipped.
> > 
> > -=
 Gordon @ IA
> > 
> > gkbrown22 wrote:
> > > Thanks Gordon, I understand th=
at many of these smaller images
may not
> > > have any bandwidth benefit on=
 this however I am trying to eliminate
> > > any images from being captured=
. Right now, even these that are being
> > > logged as "REJECT" are still g=
oing to the write processor and are
> > > being written. That is what is co=
nfusing to me. I understand
that the
> > > benefit to the server is nill bu=
t once the reject is returned
why does
> > > the FetchHTTP go and get(or re=
get) the uri?
> > > "org.archive.modules.fetcher.FetchHTTP
> > >>> innerPro=
cess GET"
> > > and then passes it on to the writer? (This is after the rej=
ection by
> > > the filter.)
> > > 
> > > This is what has me confused. 
> =
> > 
> > > thanks
> > > -glen
> > > 
> > > 
> > > I will try and capture th=
em on a filter at the writer 
> > > --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com,=
 Gordon Mohr <gojomo@> wrote:
> > >> At best, the mid-fetch filter can abor=
t a fetch that's already
begun.
> > >>
> > >> As your log shows 1x1 GIFs wa=
y smaller than a single TCP
packet, the 
> > >> abort in those cases is lik=
ely to be irrelevant to the server --
> as far 
> > >> as it's concerned, i=
t already finished serving the request.
> > >>
> > >> Even with a large GIF=
, I don't know if the server-side log would
> show 
> > >> anything other t=
han a successful response. (It would depend on how 
> > >> broken connectio=
ns are logged.)
> > >>
> > >> On the crawler side, I think even a mid-fetch=
 abort leaves the
> entry in 
> > >> the crawl.log and at least truncated c=
ontent available for
> writing to 
> > >> W/ARC files. Are you seeing or ex=
pecting something different?
> > >>
> > >> - Gordon @ IA
